{"step_by_step_thinking": "The patient's presentation of cognitive delay, seizures, cardiac murmur, and skin findings are suggestive of tuberous sclerosis complex (TSC). TSC is an autosomal dominant disorder characterized by the development of benign hamartomas in multiple organs. The most commonly affected organs are the brain, skin, heart, kidneys, and lungs. Neurologic manifestations include seizures, which often begin in infancy, and cognitive impairment. Cardiac rhabdomyomas may be present, which can cause murmurs. The skin findings in TSC are distinctive and include hypomelanotic macules, facial angiofibromas, shagreen patches, and periungual fibromas. The genetic basis of TSC involves mutations in either the TSC1 gene on chromosome 9, which codes for the protein hamartin, or the TSC2 gene on chromosome 16, which codes for the protein tuberin. These proteins act together to inhibit the mammalian target of rapamycin (mTOR) pathway, which regulates cell growth and proliferation.
